sources.sourceName: CONCENTRATED ANIMAL FEEDING OPERATIONS (PERMITTED, POINT SOURCE)
CONCENTRATED ANIMAL FEEDING OPERATIONS (PERMITTED, POINT SOURCE)

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText:
"Water Quality Standards Attainment:
The designated beneficial uses for 
 
Little Blue River (LB1-10000):

Primary Contact Recreation,
Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A,
Public Drinking Water Supply,
Agriculture Water Supply Class A and
Aesthetics. 
 
Little Blue River (LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and LB2-30000), Rock Creek (LB1-10200) and Big Sandy Creek (LB2-10100):

Primary Contact Recreation,
Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A,
Agriculture Water Supply Class A and
Aesthetics. 
 
Atrazine 
The impaired use for Little Blue River (LB1-10000), is Public Drinking Water Supply as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the Public Drinking Water Supply use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 
""004 Water Supply.004.01 Public Drinking Water.
These are surface waters which serve as a public drinking water supply. These waters must be treated (e.g., coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, chlorination) before the water is suitable for human consumption. After treatment, these waters are suitable for drinking water, food processing, and similar uses.
004.01A General Criteria. Wastes or toxic substances introduced directly or indirectly by human activity in concentrations that would degrade the use (i.e., would produce undesirable physiological effects in humans) shall not be allowed.
004.01B Numerical Criteria. Numerical criteria for the parameters listed below shall not be exceeded. Any substance introduced directly or indirectly by human activity shall not be allowed to enter surface water if one or more of the following numerical standards would be exceeded. The numerical standards listed below are intended to protect beneficial use of public drinking water supply. If the natural background level of a parameter is greater than the numerical standard, this shall not in and of itself prohibit the use of the surface water.""
 
For atrazine in Little Blue River segment LB1-10000, the criterion is 0.003 milligrams per liter or 3 micrograms per liter. For this segment, data assessment and the TMDL are based on 3 µg/L.  
 The impaired use for Little Blue River segments LB1-10000, LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and Big Sandy Creek segment LB2-10100, is Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 

""003.01C Toxic Substances. 
 
Surface waters shall be free from toxic substances, alone or in combination with other substances, in concentrations that result in acute or chronic toxicity to aquatic life, except as specified in Chapter 2. Toxic substances shall not be present in concentrations that result in objectionable tastes or significant bioaccumulation or biomagnification in aquatic organisms which renders them unsuitable or unsafe for consumption. (In implementing these criteria, the Department will follow procedures outlined in the State’s Continuing Planning Process which comply with the federal water quality standards, 40 C.F.R. § 131.11 (1987)). 
 
003.01C1 The following numerical criteria for the protection of aquatic life and their uses (e.g., fish consumption) shall not be exceeded. Unless otherwise noted, criteria are based on total concentrations.""
 
For atrazine in the Little Blue River segments LB1-10000, LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and Big Sandy Creek segment LB2-10100, the acute criteria is 330 micrograms per liter based on a one-hour average concentration and the chronic criteria is 12 µg/L based on a four-day average concentration. 
 
Assessment of the data and TMDLs for LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and LB2-10100 are based on the atrazine chronic criterion of 12 µg/L. Targeting the water supply beneficial use in LB1"

NATURAL SOURCES OR SECONDARY/TERTIARY TO PRIMARY SOURCE/CAUSE

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText:
"Water Quality Standards Attainment:
Designated beneficial uses for all Fremont State Lakes include Primary Contact Recreation, warmwater Aquatic Life Class A, Agriculture Water Supply Class A, Aesthetics and Nutrient Classification E.   
 
The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the warmwater Aquatic Life Class A use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 
""003 Aquatic Life.
003.01 General Criteria for Aquatic Life
The following criteria apply to all aquatic life use classes.
003.01A pH (Hydrogen Ion Concentration).Hydrogen Ion concentrations, expressed as pH, shall be maintained between 6.5 and 9.0; unless pH values outside this range are due to natural conditions.
 
003.04 Warmwater Aquatic Life Use Class Specific Criteria.These are waters which provide, or could provide, a habitat consisting of sufficient water volume or flow, water quality, and other characteristics such as substrate composition which are capable of maintaining year-round populations of warmwater biota. Warmwater biota are considered to be life forms in waters where temperatures frequently exceed 25°C (77°F).
003.04A Class A - Warmwater.
These waters provide, or could provide, a habitat suitable for maintaining one or more identified key species on a year-round basis. These waters also are capable of maintaining year-round populations of a variety of other warmwater fish and associated vertebrate and invertebrate organisms and plants.
003.04A1 Dissolved Oxygen.
003.04A1a One-day minimum of not less than 5.0 milligrams per liter for early life stages. This criterion applies from April 1 through September 30.
003.04A1b One-day minimum of not less than 3.0 mg/l for all life stages other than early-life stages. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.
003.04A1c Seven-day mean minimum of not less than 4.0 mg/l. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.
003.04A1d Seven-day mean of not less than 6.0 mg/l for early-life stages. This criterion applies from April 1 through September 30.
003.04A1e Thirty-day mean of not less than 5.5 mg/l. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.
 
003.05 Nutrient Criteria for Lakes and Impounded Waters.
The following criteria associated with various nutrient classifications shall apply to lakes or impounded waters according to codes listed in Chapter 6. Criteria are based on seasonal averages from April 1 through September 30. Eastern Lakes and Impounded Waters are located within the Big Blue, Little Blue, Elkhorn, Lower Platte, Missouri Tributaries and Nemaha River Basins. Western Lakes and Impounded Waters are located within the Loup, Middle Platte, Niobrara, North Platte, Republican, South Platte and White River-Hat Creek Basins. Natural Sandhill Lakes shall not be subject to these criteria as they exist in a relatively undisturbed condition. 
 
Chlorophyll-a represents the desired biological condition (response) and is generally influenced by the amount of phosphorus and nitrogen (cause).
 











Lake or Impounded Classification

Waters Codes

Total Phosphorus (micrograms per liter)

Total Nitrogen (micrograms per liter)

Chlorophyll-a (micrograms per liter)


Eastern Lakes and Impounded Waters:

E

50

1000

10


Western Lakes and Impounded Waters:

W

40

800

8


Natural Sandhill Lakes

SH

---

---

---
 
The impaired use for Fremont State Lakes is for warmwater Aquatic Life Class A use as a result of eutrophication and excess nutrients.
 
Because the criteria for aquatic life are more stringent than those criteria for the other designated uses of Fremont Lakes, attainment of TP loadings will assure full support of all the designated uses potentially impacted by nutrients.

Numeric Target(s):
Designated beneficial uses for all Fremont State Lakes include Primary Contact Recreation, warmwater Aqu"

003.04 Warmwater Aquatic Life Use Class Specific Criteria.These are waters which provide, or could provide, a habitat consisting of sufficient water volume or flow, water quality, and other characteristics such as substrate composition which are capable of maintaining year-round populations of warmwater biota. Warmwater biota are considered to be life forms in waters where temperatures frequently exceed 25°C (77°F).
003.04A Class A - Warmwater.

003.04A1 Dissolved Oxygen.

003.04A1c Seven-day mean minimum of not less than 4.0 mg/l. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.
003.04A1d Seven-day mean of not less than 6.0 mg/l for early-life stages. This criterion applies from April 1 through September 30.
003.04A1e Thirty-day mean of not less than 5.5 mg/l. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.
 
003.05 Nutrient Criteria for Lakes and Impounded Waters.
The following criteria associated with various nutrient classifications shall apply to lakes or impounded waters according to codes listed in Chapter 6. Criteria are based on seasonal averages from April 1 through September 30. Eastern Lakes and Impounded Waters are located within the Big Blue, Little Blue, Elkhorn, Lower Platte, Missouri Tributaries and Nemaha River Basins. Western Lakes and Impounded Waters are located within the Loup, Middle Platte, Niobrara, North Platte, Republican, South Platte and White River-Hat Creek Basins. Natural Sandhill Lakes shall not be subject to these criteria as they exist in a relatively undisturbed condition.

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText:
"Water Quality Standards Attainment:
The designated beneficial uses for 
 
Little Blue River (LB1-10000):

Primary Contact Recreation,
Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A,
Public Drinking Water Supply,
Agriculture Water Supply Class A and
Aesthetics. 
 
Little Blue River (LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and LB2-30000), Rock Creek (LB1-10200) and Big Sandy Creek (LB2-10100):

Primary Contact Recreation,
Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A,
Agriculture Water Supply Class A and
Aesthetics. 
 
Atrazine 
The impaired use for Little Blue River (LB1-10000), is Public Drinking Water Supply as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the Public Drinking Water Supply use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 
""004 Water Supply.004.01 Public Drinking Water.
These are surface waters which serve as a public drinking water supply. These waters must be treated (e.g., coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, chlorination) before the water is suitable for human consumption. After treatment, these waters are suitable for drinking water, food processing, and similar uses.
004.01A General Criteria. Wastes or toxic substances introduced directly or indirectly by human activity in concentrations that would degrade the use (i.e., would produce undesirable physiological effects in humans) shall not be allowed.
004.01B Numerical Criteria. Numerical criteria for the parameters listed below shall not be exceeded. Any substance introduced directly or indirectly by human activity shall not be allowed to enter surface water if one or more of the following numerical standards would be exceeded. The numerical standards listed below are intended to protect beneficial use of public drinking water supply. If the natural background level of a parameter is greater than the numerical standard, this shall not in and of itself prohibit the use of the surface water.""
 
For atrazine in Little Blue River segment LB1-10000, the criterion is 0.003 milligrams per liter or 3 micrograms per liter. For this segment, data assessment and the TMDL are based on 3 µg/L.  
 The impaired use for Little Blue River segments LB1-10000, LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and Big Sandy Creek segment LB2-10100, is Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 

""003.01C Toxic Substances. 
 
Surface waters shall be free from toxic substances, alone or in combination with other substances, in concentrations that result in acute or chronic toxicity to aquatic life, except as specified in Chapter 2. Toxic substances shall not be present in concentrations that result in objectionable tastes or significant bioaccumulation or biomagnification in aquatic organisms which renders them unsuitable or unsafe for consumption. (In implementing these criteria, the Department will follow procedures outlined in the State’s Continuing Planning Process which comply with the federal water quality standards, 40 C.F.R. § 131.11 (1987)). 
 
003.01C1 The following numerical criteria for the protection of aquatic life and their uses (e.g., fish consumption) shall not be exceeded. Unless otherwise noted, criteria are based on total concentrations.""
 
For atrazine in the Little Blue River segments LB1-10000, LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and Big Sandy Creek segment LB2-10100, the acute criteria is 330 micrograms per liter based on a one-hour average concentration and the chronic criteria is 12 µg/L based on a four-day average concentration. 
 
Assessment of the data and TMDLs for LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and LB2-10100 are based on the atrazine chronic criterion of 12 µg/L. Targeting the water supply beneficial use in LB1"

CONCENTRATED ANIMAL FEEDING OPERATIONS (PERMITTED, POINT SOURCE)

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText: THE POLLUTANT CAUSING THE IMPAIRMENT OF THE WQS AND DESIGNATED BENEFICIAL USE IS E.COLI BACTERIA. THE TMDL TARGET IS BASED DIRECTLY ON THE NUMERIC WATER QUALITY CRITERIA FOR E. COLI BACTERIA OF 126CFU/100ML, A 10% MOS HAS BEEN ASSIGNED, BUT IN NTTS IS ENTERED AS IMPLICIT BECAUSE IT IS BASED ON A % REDUCTION. THE LA IS ¡Ü113/100ML. ALL DISCHARGERS HAVE A WLA OF ¡Ü 126ML; NON DISCHARGERS HAVE A WLA OF ZERO. REFER TO EITHER THE DECISION DOCUMENT OR TMDL FOR SPECIFIC LOADING INFORMATION.

THE POLLUTANT CAUSING THE IMPAIRMENT OF THE WQS AND DESIGNATED BENEFICIAL USE IS E.COLI BACTERIA. THE TMDL TARGET IS BASED DIRECTLY ON THE NUMERIC WATER QUALITY CRITERIA FOR E. COLI BACTERIA OF 126CFU/100ML, A 10% MOS HAS BEEN ASSIGNED, BUT IN NTTS IS ENTERED AS IMPLICIT BECAUSE IT IS BASED ON A % REDUCTION. THE LA IS ¡Ü113/100ML. ALL DISCHARGERS HAVE A WLA OF ¡Ü 126ML; NON DISCHARGERS HAVE A WLA OF ZERO. REFER TO EITHER THE DECISION DOCUMENT OR TMDL FOR SPECIFIC LOADING INFORMATION.

THE POLLUTANT CAUSING THE IMPAIRMENT OF THE WQS AND DESIGNATED BENEFICIAL USE IS E.COLI BACTERIA. THE WQS IS 126CFU/ML AS A 30 DAY GEOMETRIC MEAN DURING THE RECREATIONAL PERIOD. THIS IS A DIRECT MEASURE. WLA IN THIS TMDL ARE GIVEN AS CONCENTRATION, DIRECTLY TARGETING THE CRITERION. THE LA IN THIS TMDL IS EXPRESSED AS PERCENT REDUCTIONS WHICH WILL RESULT IN THE TARGET CONCENTRATION IN THE SEGMENTS IDENTIFIED AND AS DAILY LOADS. (IN THE NATIONAL DATABASE THE DAILY LOAD IS GIVEN IN CFU/DAY, PLEASE CHECK TMDL EVEN IF THE NUMBER IS LISTED IN THE TMDL. REFER TO EITHER THE DECISION DOCUMENT OR TMDL FOR SPECIFIC LOADING INFORMATION. THIS TMDL WAS APPROVED ON 09-28-2007. REFER THE TMDL LISTED ON THIS WEBSITE FOR SPECIFIC LOADING INFORMATION FOR POINT SOURCES. HTTP://WWW.EPA.GOV/REGION07/WATER/APPRTMDL.HTM#NEBRASKA

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText:
"Water Quality Standards Attainment:
Designated beneficial uses for all Fremont State Lakes include Primary Contact Recreation, warmwater Aquatic Life Class A, Agriculture Water Supply Class A, Aesthetics and Nutrient Classification E.   
 
The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the warmwater Aquatic Life Class A use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 
""003 Aquatic Life.
003.01 General Criteria for Aquatic Life
The following criteria apply to all aquatic life use classes.
003.01A pH (Hydrogen Ion Concentration).Hydrogen Ion concentrations, expressed as pH, shall be maintained between 6.5 and 9.0; unless pH values outside this range are due to natural conditions.
 
003.04 Warmwater Aquatic Life Use Class Specific Criteria.These are waters which provide, or could provide, a habitat consisting of sufficient water volume or flow, water quality, and other characteristics such as substrate composition which are capable of maintaining year-round populations of warmwater biota. Warmwater biota are considered to be life forms in waters where temperatures frequently exceed 25°C (77°F).
003.04A Class A - Warmwater.
These waters provide, or could provide, a habitat suitable for maintaining one or more identified key species on a year-round basis. These waters also are capable of maintaining year-round populations of a variety of other warmwater fish and associated vertebrate and invertebrate organisms and plants.
003.04A1 Dissolved Oxygen.
003.04A1a One-day minimum of not less than 5.0 milligrams per liter for early life stages. This criterion applies from April 1 through September 30.
003.04A1b One-day minimum of not less than 3.0 mg/l for all life stages other than early-life stages. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.
003.04A1c Seven-day mean minimum of not less than 4.0 mg/l. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.
003.04A1d Seven-day mean of not less than 6.0 mg/l for early-life stages. This criterion applies from April 1 through September 30.
003.04A1e Thirty-day mean of not less than 5.5 mg/l. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.
 
003.05 Nutrient Criteria for Lakes and Impounded Waters.
The following criteria associated with various nutrient classifications shall apply to lakes or impounded waters according to codes listed in Chapter 6. Criteria are based on seasonal averages from April 1 through September 30. Eastern Lakes and Impounded Waters are located within the Big Blue, Little Blue, Elkhorn, Lower Platte, Missouri Tributaries and Nemaha River Basins. Western Lakes and Impounded Waters are located within the Loup, Middle Platte, Niobrara, North Platte, Republican, South Platte and White River-Hat Creek Basins. Natural Sandhill Lakes shall not be subject to these criteria as they exist in a relatively undisturbed condition. 
 
Chlorophyll-a represents the desired biological condition (response) and is generally influenced by the amount of phosphorus and nitrogen (cause).
 











Lake or Impounded Classification

Waters Codes

Total Phosphorus (micrograms per liter)

Total Nitrogen (micrograms per liter)

Chlorophyll-a (micrograms per liter)

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText:
"Water Quality Standards Attainment:
The designated beneficial uses for 
 
Little Blue River (LB1-10000):

Primary Contact Recreation,
Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A,
Public Drinking Water Supply,
Agriculture Water Supply Class A and
Aesthetics. 
 
Little Blue River (LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and LB2-30000), Rock Creek (LB1-10200) and Big Sandy Creek (LB2-10100):

Primary Contact Recreation,
Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A,
Agriculture Water Supply Class A and
Aesthetics. 
 
Atrazine 
The impaired use for Little Blue River (LB1-10000), is Public Drinking Water Supply as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the Public Drinking Water Supply use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 
""004 Water Supply.004.01 Public Drinking Water.
These are surface waters which serve as a public drinking water supply. These waters must be treated (e.g., coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, chlorination) before the water is suitable for human consumption. After treatment, these waters are suitable for drinking water, food processing, and similar uses.
004.01A General Criteria. Wastes or toxic substances introduced directly or indirectly by human activity in concentrations that would degrade the use (i.e., would produce undesirable physiological effects in humans) shall not be allowed.
004.01B Numerical Criteria. Numerical criteria for the parameters listed below shall not be exceeded. Any substance introduced directly or indirectly by human activity shall not be allowed to enter surface water if one or more of the following numerical standards would be exceeded. The numerical standards listed below are intended to protect beneficial use of public drinking water supply. If the natural background level of a parameter is greater than the numerical standard, this shall not in and of itself prohibit the use of the surface water.""
 
For atrazine in Little Blue River segment LB1-10000, the criterion is 0.003 milligrams per liter or 3 micrograms per liter. For this segment, data assessment and the TMDL are based on 3 µg/L.  
 The impaired use for Little Blue River segments LB1-10000, LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and Big Sandy Creek segment LB2-10100, is Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 

""003.01C Toxic Substances. 
 
Surface waters shall be free from toxic substances, alone or in combination with other substances, in concentrations that result in acute or chronic toxicity to aquatic life, except as specified in Chapter 2. Toxic substances shall not be present in concentrations that result in objectionable tastes or significant bioaccumulation or biomagnification in aquatic organisms which renders them unsuitable or unsafe for consumption. (In implementing these criteria, the Department will follow procedures outlined in the State’s Continuing Planning Process which comply with the federal water quality standards, 40 C.F.R. § 131.11 (1987)). 
 
003.01C1 The following numerical criteria for the protection of aquatic life and their uses (e.g., fish consumption) shall not be exceeded. Unless otherwise noted, criteria are based on total concentrations.""
 
For atrazine in the Little Blue River segments LB1-10000, LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and Big Sandy Creek segment LB2-10100, the acute criteria is 330 micrograms per liter based on a one-hour average concentration and the chronic criteria is 12 µg/L based on a four-day average concentration. 
 
Assessment of the data and TMDLs for LB2-10000, LB2-20000 and LB2-10100 are based on the atrazine chronic criterion of 12 µg/L. Targeting the water supply beneficial use in LB1"

These waters provide, or could provide, a habitat suitable for maintaining one or more identified key species on a year-round basis. These waters also are capable of maintaining year-round populations of a variety of other warmwater fish and associated vertebrate and invertebrate organisms and plants.
003.04A1 Dissolved Oxygen.
003.04A1a One-day minimum of not less than 5.0 milligrams per liter for early life stages. This criterion applies from April 1 through September 30.
003.04A1b One-day minimum of not less than 3.0 mg/l for all life stages other than early-life stages. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.
003.04A1c Seven-day mean minimum of not less than 4.0 mg/l. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.
003.04A1d Seven-day mean of not less than 6.0 mg/l for early-life stages. This criterion applies from April 1 through September 30.
003.04A1e Thirty-day mean of not less than 5.5 mg/l. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.
 
003.05 Nutrient Criteria for Lakes and Impounded Waters.
The following criteria associated with various nutrient classifications shall apply to lakes or impounded waters according to codes listed in Chapter 6. Criteria are based on seasonal averages from April 1 through September 30. Eastern Lakes and Impounded Waters are located within the Big Blue, Little Blue, Elkhorn, Lower Platte, Missouri Tributaries and Nemaha River Basins. Western Lakes and Impounded Waters are located within the Loup, Middle Platte, Niobrara, North Platte, Republican, South Platte and White River-Hat Creek Basins. Natural Sandhill Lakes shall not be subject to these criteria as they exist in a relatively undisturbed condition. 
 
Chlorophyll-a represents the desired biological condition (response) and is generally influenced by the amount of phosphorus and nitrogen (cause).

Designated beneficial uses for all Fremont State Lakes include Primary Contact Recreation, warmwater Aquatic Life Class A, Agriculture Water Supply Class A, Aesthetics and Nutrient Classification E.   
 
The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the warmwater Aquatic Life Class A use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 
""003 Aquatic Life.
003.01 General Criteria for Aquatic Life
The following criteria apply to all aquatic life use classes.
003.01A pH (Hydrogen Ion Concentration).Hydrogen Ion concentrations, expressed as pH, shall be maintained between 6.5 and 9.0; unless pH values outside this range are due to natural conditions.
 
003.04 Warmwater Aquatic Life Use Class Specific Criteria.These are waters which provide, or could provide, a habitat consisting of sufficient water volume or flow, water quality, and other characteristics such as substrate composition which are capable of maintaining year-round populations of warmwater biota. Warmwater biota are considered to be life forms in waters where temperatures frequently exceed 25°C (77°F).
003.04A Class A - Warmwater.
These waters provide, or could provide, a habitat suitable for maintaining one or more identified key species on a year-round basis. These waters also are capable of maintaining year-round populations of a variety of other warmwater fish and associated vertebrate and invertebrate organisms and plants.

003.04A1e Thirty-day mean of not less than 5.5 mg/l. This criterion applies from October 1 through March 31.

EMPIRICAL DATA AND THE EUTROMOD WATER QUALITY MODEL WERE EMPLOYED TO DETERMINE THE CURRENT AND MAXIMUM NUTRIENT LOAD THAT IF ACHIEVED SHOULD RESULT IN BENEFICIAL USE ATTAINMENT.  THIS VALUE IS 2,379 LBS/YEAR FOR PHOSPHORUS.  EMPIRICAL DATA OBTAINED FROM DESIGN PLANS AND BATHYMETRIC SURVEYS WERE EMPLOYED TO DETERMINE THE CURRENT AVERAGE ANNUAL SEDIMENT LOAD AND THE STAKEHOLDER DERIVED WATER QUALITY TARGET THAT IF ACHIEVED WILL RESULT IN BENEFICIAL USE ATTAINMENT. THIS VALUE IS 9,200 TONS/YEAR.  THE AVERAGE ANNUAL TOTAL PHOSPHORUS LOAD DELIVERED TO IRON HORSE IS ESTIMATED TO BE 9,827 LBS/YEAR.  TO MEET THE WATER QUALITY GOALS, THE AVERAGE ANNUAL LOADING CAPACITY IS 2,379 LBS/YEAR AND APPROX. A 76% REDUCTION. THE AVERAGE ANNUAL SEDIMENT LOAD DELIVERED TO IRON HORSE TRAIL LAKE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE 24,966 TONS/YEAR. TO MEET THE WATER QUALITY GOALS, THE AVERAGE ANNUAL LOADING CAPACITY IS 9,200 TONS/YEAR AND APPROX A 63% REDUCTION. THE WATER QUALITY ENDPOINTS FOR THIS TMDL WILL BE TOTAL PHOSPHORUS AND CHLOROPHYLL A WITH THE REGIONALLY BASED WATER QUALITY TARGETS FOR IRON HORSE TRAIL LAKE BEING .143 MG/L AND 16MG/M3, RESPECTIVELY. THE WASTE LOAD ALLOCATION IS ZERO AND THE LOAD ALLOCATION IS 2,353 POUNDS/YEAR OF PHOSPHORUS.

THE POLLUTANT CAUSING THE IMPAIRMENT(S) OF THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS AND DESIGNATED BENEFICIAL USE IS E. COLI BACTERIA.  
 
DESIGNATED USES ASSIGNED TO ALL SEGMENTS:  
STATE RESOURCE WATERS, PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION, COLDWATER CLASS A AND B AQUATIC LIFE, WARMWATER CLASS A AND B AQUATIC LIFE, AGRICULTURAL CLASS A WATER SUPPLY AND AESTHETICS (NDEQ 2009A).
 
THE TMDL STATES THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS AS: 002.01 E. COLI ""E. COLI SHALL NOT EXCEED A GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 COLONY FORMING UNIT PER 100 MILLILITERS. FOR INCREASED CONFIDENCE OF THE CRITERIA, THE GEOMETRIC MEAN SHOULD BE BASED ON A MINIMUM OF FIVE SAMPLES TAKEN WITHIN A 20-DAY PERIOD. THIS DOES NOT PRECLUDE FECAL COLIFORM LIMITATIONS BASED ON EFFLUENT GUIDELINES. THE FOLLOWING SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM SHALL BE USED SOLELY FOR ISSUING PERIODIC PUBLIC ADVISORIES REGARDING USE OF WATER BODIES FOR PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION."" TITLE 117, CHAPTER 4. THIS CRITERIA WAS ESTABLISHED FOR THE PROTECTION OF THE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION BENEFICIAL USE.

"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
THE DESIGNATED BENEFICIAL USES FOR MUD CREEK SEGMENTS LO4-10100 AND LO4-10200 INCLUDE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION, WARM WATER AQUATIC LIFE - CLASS B, AGRICULTURE WATER SUPPLY CLASS A AND AESTHETICS. 
 
ATRAZINE 
THE APPLICABLE NUMERIC WATER QUALITY CRITERIA ESTABLISHED FOR PROTECTION OF THE CLASS B ¿ WARM WATER AQUATIC LIFE USE CAN BE FOUND IN TITLE 117, CHAPTER 4, NEBRASKA SURFACE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS, 2006. 
 

003.01C TOXIC SUBSTANCES. 
 
SURFACE WATERS SHALL BE FREE FROM TOXIC SUBSTANCES, ALONE OR IN COMBINATION WITH OTHER SUBSTANCES, IN CONCENTRATIONS THAT RESULT IN ACUTE OR CHRONIC TOXICITY TO AQUATIC LIFE, EXCEPT AS SPECIFIED IN CHAPTER 2. TOXIC SUBSTANCES SHALL NOT BE PRESENT IN CONCENTRATIONS THAT RESULT IN OBJECTIONABLE TASTES OR SIGNIFICANT BIOACCUMULATION OR BIOMAGNIFICATION IN AQUATIC ORGANISMS WHICH RENDERS THEM UNSUITABLE OR UNSAFE FOR CONSUMPTION. (IN IMPLEMENTING THESE CRITERIA, THE DEPARTMENT WILL FOLLOW PROCEDURES OUTLINED IN THE STATE¿S CONTINUING PLANNING PROCESS WHICH COMPLY WITH THE FEDERAL WATER QUALITY STANDARDS, 40 C.F.R. § 131.11 (1987)). 
 
003.01C1 THE FOLLOWING NUMERICAL CRITERIA FOR THE PROTECTION OF AQUATIC LIFE AND THEIR USES (E.G., FISH CONSUMPTION) SHALL NOT BE EXCEEDED. UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED, CRITERIA ARE BASED ON TOTAL CONCENTRATIONS. 
 
FOR ATRAZINE, THE ACUTE CRITERIA IS 330 MICROGRAMS PER LITER BASED ON A ONE-HOUR AVERAGE CONCENTRATION AND THE CHRONIC CRITERIA IS 12 UG/L BASED ON A FOUR-DAY AVERAGE CONCENTRATION.
   
ASSESSMENT OF THE DATA AND THE TMDL ARE BASED ON THE ATRAZINE CHRONIC CRITERION OF 12 UG/L. THE IMPAIRED USE FOR SEGMENT LO4-10100 IS WARM WATER AQUATIC LIFE - CLASS B AS A RESULT OF THE POLLUTANT ATRAZINE.
 
ESCHERICHIA COLI 
WATER QUALITY CRITERIA ESTABLISHED FOR THE PROTECTION OF THE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION BENEFICIAL USE CAN BE FOUND IN TITLE 117, CHAPTER 4, NEBRASKA SURFACE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS, 2006. 
 

002 PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION.
THIS USE APPLIES TO SURFACE WATERS WHICH ARE USED, OR HAVE A HIGH POTENTIAL TO BE USED, FOR PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES. PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION INCLUDES ACTIVITIES WHERE THE BODY MAY COME INTO PROLONGED OR INTIMATE CONTACT WITH THE WATER, SUCH THAT WATER MAY BE ACCIDENTALLY INGESTED AND SENSITIVE BODY ORGANS (E.G., EYES, EARS, NOSE, ETC.) MAY BE EXPOSED. ALTHOUGH THE WATER MAY BE ACCIDENTALLY INGESTED, IT IS NOT INTENDED TO BE USED AS A POTABLE WATER SUPPLY UNLESS ACCEPTABLE TREATMENT IS APPLIED. THESE WATERS MAY BE USED FOR SWIMMING, WATER SKIING, CANOEING, AND SIMILAR ACTIVITIES. THESE CRITERIA APPLY DURING THE RECREATIONAL PERIOD OF MAY 1 THROUGH SEPTEMBER 30.
 
002.01 E. COLI. 
E. COLI BACTERIA SHALL NOT EXCEED A GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126/100 ML. FOR INCREASED CONFIDENCE OF THE CRITERIA, THE GEOMETRIC MEAN SHOULD BE BASED ON A MINIMUM OF FIVE SAMPLES TAKEN WITHIN A 30-DAY PERIOD. THIS DOES NOT PRECLUDE FECAL COLIFORM LIMITATIONS BASED ON EFFLUENT GUIDELINES. SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE DENSITIES SHALL NOT EXCEED THE FOLLOWING CRITERIA.  
 
002.01A 235/100 ML AT DESIGNATED BATHING BEACHES 
002.01B 298/100 ML AT MODERATELY USED RECREATIONAL WATERS 
002.01C 406/100 ML AT LIGHTLY USED RECREATIONAL WATERS 
002.01D 576/100 ML AT INFREQUENTLY USED RECREATIONAL WATERS.
 
THE IMPAIRED USE FOR SEGMENTS LO4-10100 AND LO4-10200 IS PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION USE AS A RESULT OF THE POLLUTANT E. COLI.

TO ACHIEVE WQS FOR PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION "BACTERIA OF THE FECAL COLIFORM GROUP SHALL NOT EXCEED A GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 200/100 ML, NOR EXCEED 400/100 ML, IN MORE THAN 10% OF THE SAMPLES."E.COLI BACTERIA SHALL NOT EXCEED A GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126/100 ML. THESE CRITERIA ARE BASED UPON A MINIMUM OF 5 SAMPLES TAKEN WITHIN A 30 DAY PERIOD. THIS CRITERIA APPLY DURING THE RECREATIONAL PERIOD OF MAY 1 THROUGH SEPTEMBER 30. WQS SHOULD BE ACHIEVED BASED ON THE REDUCTIONS LISTED. RE1-10000 - 111/100 ML A 36% REDUCTION, RE1-20000 - 110/100 ML A 70% REDUCTION, RE2-10000(1)- 110/100 ML A 75% REDUCTION, RE2-10000(2)- 113/100 ML A 26% REDUCTION, RE3-10000 - 110/100 ML AN 58% REDUCTION, AND RE3-20300 - 111/100 ML AN 80% REDUCTION.

"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
THE POLLUTANT CAUSING THE IMPAIRMENT(S) OF THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS AND DESIGNATED BENEFICIAL USE IS E. COLI BACTERIA.  
 
DESIGNATED USES ASSIGNED TO ALL SEGMENTS:  
STATE RESOURCE WATERS, PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION, COLDWATER CLASS A AND B AQUATIC LIFE, WARMWATER CLASS A AND B AQUATIC LIFE, AGRICULTURAL CLASS A WATER SUPPLY AND AESTHETICS (NDEQ 2009A).
 
THE TMDL STATES THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS AS: 002.01 E. COLI ""E. COLI SHALL NOT EXCEED A GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 COLONY FORMING UNIT PER 100 MILLILITERS. FOR INCREASED CONFIDENCE OF THE CRITERIA, THE GEOMETRIC MEAN SHOULD BE BASED ON A MINIMUM OF FIVE SAMPLES TAKEN WITHIN A 20-DAY PERIOD. THIS DOES NOT PRECLUDE FECAL COLIFORM LIMITATIONS BASED ON EFFLUENT GUIDELINES. THE FOLLOWING SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM SHALL BE USED SOLELY FOR ISSUING PERIODIC PUBLIC ADVISORIES REGARDING USE OF WATER BODIES FOR PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION."" TITLE 117, CHAPTER 4. THIS CRITERIA WAS ESTABLISHED FOR THE PROTECTION OF THE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION BENEFICIAL USE. 
 

002.01A- 235 COLONY FORMING UNITS PER 100 MILLILITERS AT DESIGNATED BATHING BEACHES
002.01B- 298 COLONY FORMING UNITS PER 100 MILLILITERS AT MODERATELY USED RECREATIONAL WATERS
002.01C- 406 COLONY FORMING UNITS PER 100 MILLILITERS AT LIGHTLY USED RECREATIONAL WATERS
002.01D- 576 COLONY FORMING UNITS PER 100 MILLILITERS AT INFREQUENTLY USED RECREATIONAL WATERS
 
EXCESSIVE E. COLI HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE IMPAIRING THE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION DESIGNATED USE. WATER QUALITY TARGETS FOR E. COLI BACTERIA ARE 126 CFU/100 ML AS A GEOMETRIC MEAN AND WILL APPLY TO ALL SEGMENTS LISTED IN THIS TMDL DOCUMENT DURING THE RECREATIONAL PERIOD OF MAY 1 - SEPTEMBER 30.

documents.documentComments: This is the approved TMDL for Lake Ogallala for DO for TP, TN and Chlorophyll-A. Approved 9/28/2007.
EPA's decision document for Lake Ogallala TMDL approval.
This is the approval letter from EPA to NEE approving the Lake Ogallala TMDL on 9/28/2007.

associatedPollutants.implicitMarginofSafetyText: Implicit Margin of Safety, The modeling assumption assumes a worst-case situation of incoming water DO concentration.
associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText:
CE-QUAL-W2 modeling efforts have demonstrated the most significant factors contributing to low DO in Lake Ogallala are macrophyte respiration, IOD caused by hydrogen sulfide oxidation and low DO water from Lake McConaughy’s hypolimnion.  For this TMDL, the loading was estimated using a combination of models and chemical data.  CE-QUAL-W2 was the water quality model used.

No point sources discharge to Lake Ogallala and due to the limited watershed, a majority of the water delivered is from Lake McConaughy.  Based on this finding, the entire source of the pollutants in Lake Ogallala is due to nonpoint sources.

Because no point sources discharge directly to Lake Ogallala the wasteload allocation will be zero (0).

associatedPollutants.implicitMarginofSafetyText: Implicit Margin of Safety, The modeling assumption assumes a worst-case situation of incoming water DO concentration.
associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText: Establishment of the load allocation (LA) identifies the dynamic and unique nature of Lake Ogallala and the incoming water from Lake McConaughy and will be established according to the macrophyte density.  The load allocations will also include the contribution from background sources.  The LA can be found in Table 2.4.2 of the TMDL.

associatedPollutants.implicitMarginofSafetyText: Implicit Margin of Safety, The modeling assumption assumes a worst-case situation of incoming water DO concentration.

No point sources discharge to Lake Ogallala and due to the limited watershed, a majority of the water delivered is from Lake McConaughy.  Based on this finding, the entire source of the pollutants in Lake Ogallala is due to nonpoint sources.

Because no point sources discharge directly to Lake Ogallala the wasteload allocation will be zero (0). See TMDL for exact Loading.

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText: TO ACHIEVE WQS FOR PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION "BACTERIA OF THE FECAL COLIFORM GROUP SHALL NOT EXCEED A GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 200/100 ML, NOR EXCEED 400/100 ML, IN MORE THAN 10% OF THE SAMPLES."E.COLI BACTERIA SHALL NOT EXCEED A GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126/100 ML. THESE CRITERIA ARE BASED UPON A MINIMUM OF 5 SAMPLES TAKEN WITHIN A 30 DAY PERIOD. THIS CRITERIA APPLY DURING THE RECREATIONAL PERIOD OF MAY 1 THROUGH SEPTEMBER 30. WQS SHOULD BE ACHIEVED BASED ON THE REDUCTIONS LISTED.  LB1-10000 - 110/100 ML AN 89% REDUCTION,LB2-10000 - 110/100 ML A 76% REDUCTION.

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText:
"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
THE POLLUTANT CAUSING THE IMPAIRMENT(S) OF THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS AND DESIGNATED BENEFICIAL USE IS E. COLI BACTERIA.  
 
DESIGNATED USES ASSIGNED TO ALL SEGMENTS:  
STATE RESOURCE WATERS, PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION, COLDWATER CLASS A AND B AQUATIC LIFE, WARMWATER CLASS A AND B AQUATIC LIFE, AGRICULTURAL CLASS A WATER SUPPLY AND AESTHETICS (NDEQ 2009A).
 
THE TMDL STATES THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS AS: 002.01 E. COLI ""E. COLI SHALL NOT EXCEED A GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 COLONY FORMING UNIT PER 100 MILLILITERS. FOR INCREASED CONFIDENCE OF THE CRITERIA, THE GEOMETRIC MEAN SHOULD BE BASED ON A MINIMUM OF FIVE SAMPLES TAKEN WITHIN A 20-DAY PERIOD. THIS DOES NOT PRECLUDE FECAL COLIFORM LIMITATIONS BASED ON EFFLUENT GUIDELINES. THE FOLLOWING SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM SHALL BE USED SOLELY FOR ISSUING PERIODIC PUBLIC ADVISORIES REGARDING USE OF WATER BODIES FOR PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION."" TITLE 117, CHAPTER 4. THIS CRITERIA WAS ESTABLISHED FOR THE PROTECTION OF THE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION BENEFICIAL USE.

EXCESSIVE E. COLI HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE IMPAIRING THE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION DESIGNATED USE. WATER QUALITY TARGETS FOR E. COLI BACTERIA ARE 126 CFU/100 ML AS A GEOMETRIC MEAN AND WILL APPLY TO ALL SEGMENTS LISTED IN THIS TMDL DOCUMENT DURING THE RECREATIONAL PERIOD OF MAY 1 - SEPTEMBER 30.         

NUMERIC TARGET(S):
THE POLLUTANT CAUSING THE IMPAIRMENT(S) OF THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS AND DESIGNATED BENEFICIAL USE IS E. COLI BACTERIA.  
 
DESIGNATED USES ASSIGNED TO ALL SEGMENTS:  
STATE RESOURCE WATERS, PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION, COLDWATER CLASS A AND B AQUATIC LIFE, WARMWATER CLASS A AND B AQUATIC LIFE, AGRICULTURAL CLASS A WATER SUPPLY AND AESTHETICS (NDEQ 2009A).
 
THE TMDL STATES THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS AS: 002.01 E. COLI ""E. COLI SHALL NOT EXCEED A GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 COLONY FORMING UNIT PER 100 MILLILITERS. FOR INCREASED CONFIDENCE OF THE CRITERIA, THE GEOMETRIC MEAN SHOULD BE BASED ON A MINIMUM OF FIVE SAMPLES TAKEN WITHIN A 20-DAY PERIOD. THIS DOES NOT PRECLUDE FECAL COLIFORM LIMITATIONS BASED ON EFFLUENT GUIDELINES. THE FOLLOWING SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM SHALL BE USED SOLELY FOR ISSUING PERIODIC PUBLIC ADVISORIES REGARDING USE OF WATER BODIES FOR PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION."" TITLE 117, CHAPTER 4. THIS CRITERIA WAS ESTABLISHED FOR THE PROTECTION OF THE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION BENEFICIAL USE. 
 

002.01A- 235 COLONY FORMING UNITS PER 100 MILLILITERS AT DESIGNATED BATHING BEACHES
002.01B- 298 COLONY FORMING UNITS PER 100 MILLILITERS AT MODERATELY USED RECREATIONAL WATERS
002.01C- 406 COLONY FORMING UNITS PER 100 MILLILITERS AT LIGHTLY USED RECREATIONAL WATERS
002.01D- 576 COLONY FORMING UNITS PER 100 MILLILITERS AT INFREQUENTLY USED RECREATIONAL WATERS
 
EXCESSIVE E. COLI HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE IMPAIRING THE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION DESIGNATED USE. WATER QUALITY TARGETS FOR E. COLI BACTERIA ARE 126 CFU/100 ML AS A GEOMETRIC MEAN AND WILL APPLY TO ALL SEGMENTS LISTED IN THIS TMDL DOCUMENT DURING THE RECREATIONAL PERIOD OF MAY 1 - SEPTEMBER 30.         "
NOT ENTERED

The beneficial uses are primary contact recreation, aquatic life (warm water class A), agriculture water supply (class A) and aesthetics. The impaired use targeted by the TMDL is Primary Contact Recreation, it is impaired because of excessive algal toxins. There is no numeric water quality standard for algal toxins, the number target was determined by state agencies to address conditions considered safe for primary contact recreation. Phosphorus was targeted to reduce algal toxin (microcystin) concentrations to 20 micrograms per liter or lower. This linkage is defined through the tropic state index method (TSI) which relates algal biomass to phosphorus concentrations. This target phosphorus concentration is 47 micrograms per liter.

"Water Quality Standards Attainment:
The Designated Uses of Big Blue River Basin segments BB1-10000, BB1-20000, BB4-10000, BB4-20000, Mission Creek segment BB1-10100, Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10800, Turkey Creek segments BB2-10000, BB2-20000 and West Fork Big Blue River segments BB3-10000, BB3-20000 are:

Primary Contact Recreation,
Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A,  
Agriculture Water Supply Class A and
Aesthetics. 
 
The Designated Uses of Big Blue River segment BB4-40000, Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10900, Beaver Creek segment BB3-10300 and Lincoln Creek segment BB4-20800 are:

Warm Water Aquatic Life Class B,
Agriculture Water Supply Class A and
Aesthetics. 
 
Atrazine 
The Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A use of Big Blue River segments BB1-10000, BB1-20000, BB4-10000, Mission Creek segment BB1-10100, Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10800, Turkey Creek segments BB2-10000, BB2-20000 and West Fork Big Blue River segments BB3-10000, BB3-20000 is impaired as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The Warm Water Aquatic Life Class B use of Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10900, Beaver Creek segment BB3-10300, Lincoln Creek segment BB4-20800 and Big Blue River segment BB4-40000 is impaired as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A use and Class B use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. The following criteria apply to all aquatic life use classes: 
 

""003.01C Toxic Substances. Surface waters shall be free from toxic substances, alone or in combination with other substances, in concentrations that result in acute or chronic toxicity to aquatic life, except as specified in Chapter 2. Toxic substances shall not be present in concentrations that result in objectionable tastes or significant bioaccumulation or biomagnification in aquatic organisms which renders them unsuitable or unsafe for consumption. (In implementing these criteria, the Department will follow procedures outlined in the State’s Continuing Planning Process which comply with the federal water quality standards, 40 C.F.R. § 131.11 (1987))."" 
 
Numerical criteria for the protection of aquatic life and their uses (e.g., fish consumption) shall not be exceeded. Acute criterion for atrazine is established at 330 micrograms per liter based on a one-hour average concentration; and the chronic criterion for atrazine is 12 micrograms per liter based on a four-day average concentration. Assessment of the data and TMDLs are based on the atrazine chronic criterion of 12 µg/L. 
 
Escherichia coli The Primary Contact Recreation use of Big Blue River segments BB1-10000, BB1-20000, BB4-10000, Mission Creek segment BB1-10100, Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10800, Turkey Creek segments BB2-10000, BB2-20000 and West Fork Big Blue River segments BB3-10000, BB3-20000, is impaired as a result of the pollutant E. coli. Water quality criteria established for the protection of the Primary Contact Recreation beneficial use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 

""002 Primary Contact Recreation. This use applies to surface waters which are used, or have a high potential to be used, for primary contact recreational activities. Primary contact recreation includes activities where the body may come into prolonged or intimate contact with the water, such that water may be accidentally ingested and sensitive body organs (e.g., eyes, ears, nose, etc.) may be exposed. Although the water may be accidentally ingested, it is not intended to be used as a potable water supply unless acceptable treatment is applied. These waters may be used for swimming, water skiing, canoeing and similar activities. These criteria apply during the recreational period of May 1 th"

The Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A use of Big Blue River segments BB1-10000, BB1-20000, BB4-10000, Mission Creek segment BB1-10100, Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10800, Turkey Creek segments BB2-10000, BB2-20000 and West Fork Big Blue River segments BB3-10000, BB3-20000 is impaired as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The Warm Water Aquatic Life Class B use of Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10900, Beaver Creek segment BB3-10300, Lincoln Creek segment BB4-20800 and Big Blue River segment BB4-40000 is impaired as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A use and Class B use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. The following criteria apply to all aquatic life use classes: 
 

""003.01C Toxic Substances. Surface waters shall be free from toxic substances, alone or in combination with other substances, in concentrations that result in acute or chronic toxicity to aquatic life, except as specified in Chapter 2. Toxic substances shall not be present in concentrations that result in objectionable tastes or significant bioaccumulation or biomagnification in aquatic organisms which renders them unsuitable or unsafe for consumption. (In implementing these criteria, the Department will follow procedures outlined in the State’s Continuing Planning Process which comply with the federal water quality standards, 40 C.F.R. § 131.11 (1987))."" 
 
Numerical criteria for the protection of aquatic life and their uses (e.g., fish consumption) shall not be exceeded. Acute criterion for atrazine is established at 330 micrograms per liter based on a one-hour average concentration; and the chronic criterion for atrazine is 12 micrograms per liter based on a four-day average concentration. Assessment of the data and TMDLs are based on the atrazine chronic criterion of 12 µg/L. 
 
Escherichia coli The Primary Contact Recreation use of Big Blue River segments BB1-10000, BB1-20000, BB4-10000, Mission Creek segment BB1-10100, Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10800, Turkey Creek segments BB2-10000, BB2-20000 and West Fork Big Blue River segments BB3-10000, BB3-20000, is impaired as a result of the pollutant E. coli. Water quality criteria established for the protection of the Primary Contact Recreation beneficial use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 

""002 Primary Contact Recreation. This use applies to surface waters which are used, or have a high potential to be used, for primary contact recreational activities. Primary contact recreation includes activities where the body may come into prolonged or intimate contact with the water, such that water may be accidentally ingested and sensitive body organs (e.g., eyes, ears, nose, etc.) may be exposed. Although the water may be accidentally ingested, it is not intended to be used as a potable water supply unless acceptable treatment is applied. These waters may be used for swimming, water skiing, canoeing and similar activities. These criteria apply during the recreational period of May 1 th"

LOADS ARE QUANTIFIED WITH FLOW DURATION CURVES FOR THESE TMDLS, BASED UPON THE POSITION OF THE MONITORING DATA POINTS IN RELATION TO THE BOUNDARY ESTABLISHED ON THE TMDL CURVE BETWEEN POINT SOURCE AND NONPOINT SOURCE INFLUENCES.  THIS PROCESS FOR SELECTING THE LOAD POINT IS DESCRIBED IN THE DOCUMENT ENTITLED NEBRASKA�S APPROACH FOR DEVELOPING TMDLS FOR STREAMS USING THE LOAD DURATION CURVE METHODOLOGY.  BENEFICIAL USES FOR ALL SEGMENTS ARE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION, AQUATIC LIFE - WARM WATER CLASS A OR COLD WATER CLASS B, AGRICULTURAL WATER SUPPLY CLASS A AND AESTHETICS. WATER QUALITY TARGETS FOR E. COLI BACTERIA ARE 126 CFU/100ML AS A GEOMETRIC MEAN AND WILL APPLY TO ALL SEGMENTS LISTED IN THIS TMDL DURING THE RECREATIONAL PERIOD OF MAY 1 � SEPTEMBER 30. THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE TARGETED POLLUTANT AND THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS IS DIRECT. NPDES REGULATED POINT SOURCE LOADS ARE SET AT WQS OF A MONTHLY GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126CFU/100ML AT THE �END OF PIPE� FOR ALL SEGMENTS DISCHARGING DIRECTLY TO A RECREATIONAL SEGMENT. DRY WEATHER DISCHARGES ARE LIMITED TO A SEASONAL GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 CFU/100 ML AND NON-DISCHARGING FACILITIES ARE LIMITED TO ZERO (0) CFU.  SOURCES OF E. COLI BACTERIA IN THE WATERSHEDS FOR THESE SEGMENTS INCLUDE POINT AND NONPOINT. THERE ARE A TOTAL OF 26 NPDES PERMITTED FACILITIES IN THE BASIN. BY SEGMENT THE PERMITTED FACILITIES ARE; COLUMBUS WWTF (NE0035025), MONROE WWTF (NE0046221), GENOA WWTF (NE0027341), ALBION WWTF (NE0026573), ST EDWARD WWTF (NE0027332), AND PETERSBURG WWTF (NE0029157) IN SEGMENT LO1-1000; WOLBACH WWTF (NE0040088) AND GREELEY WWTF (NE0049212) IN SEGMENT LO1-3000; CEDAR RAPIDS WWTF (NE0049158), FULLERTON WWTF (NE0026638), PRIMROSE WWTF (NE0029220), AND SPALDING WWTF (NE0112909) IN SEGMENT LO1-30300; BURWELL WWTF (NE0021172), ORD WWTF (NE0024392), AND SCOTIA WWTF (NE0023973) IN SEGMENT LO2-10000; NGPC � CALAMUS FISH HATCHERY (NE0124745) IN SEGMENT LO2-11300; TAYLOR WWTF (NE0113000) IN SEGMENT LO2-20000; LOUP CITY WWTF (NE0045250), ST. PAUL WWTF (NE0027324), DANNEBROG WWTF (NE0045136), AND ASHTON WWTF (NE0024350) IN SEGMENT LO3-10000; ARCADIA WWTF (NE0041297) IN SEGMENT LO3-30000; RAVENNA WWTF (NE0021547) IN SEGMENT LO4-10000; ANSLEY WWTF (NE0043249) AND BROKEN BOW WWTF (NE0027260) IN SEGMENT LO4-10200; AND ARNOLD WWTF (NE0028096) INSEGMENT LO4-30000. ADDITIONAL POINT SOURCES INCLUDE NUMEROUS ANIMAL FEEDING OPERATIONS AND POSSIBLE ILLICIT DISCHARGES. NONPOINT SOURCES INCLUDE FAILING SEPTIC TANKS, ONSITE WASTEWATER SYSTEMS, RUN-OFF FROM LIVESTOCK PASTURES, IMPROPER OR OVER-APPLICATION OF BIOSOLIDS, URBAN STORM WATER NOT REGULATED BY PERMIT AND NATURAL SOURCES FROM WILDLIFE. NONPOINT SOURCE REDUCTIONS WERE DERIVED USING FLOW DURATION CURVES FOR E. COLI. TMDLS FOR THE SEGMENTS ARE GIVEN AS PERCENT REDUCTIONS BY SEGMENT, FOR NONPOINT SOURCES; LO1-10000 (81%), LO1-30000 (42%), LO1-30300 (75%), LO2-10000 44%), LO2-11400 (67%), LO2-30000 (26%), LO2-40000 (46%), LO3-10000 (46%), LO3-50300 (57%), LO4-10000 (66%), AND LO4-20000 (72%). THE MARGIN OF SAFETY IS CALCULATED AS AN EXTRA PERCENT REDUCTION OF LA TO TARGET CONCENTRATIONS 10% BELOW THE CRITERION.  THESE TMDLS ASSUMED THE EFFLUENTS DISCHARGE THE E. COLI DENSITY ALLOWED BY THE WLA OR 126/100 ML.  WWTF DISINFECTION SYSTEMS ARE OFTEN DESIGNED AND OPERATED TO ACHIEVE 100% REDUCTION IN THE INDICATOR BACTERIA OR 0/100ML.  THUS, THE ACTUAL NPDES PERMITTED POINT SOURCE CONTRIBUTION IS LIKELY LESS THAN EXPECTED BY THE TMDL.

THE MARGIN OF SAFETY IS CALCULATED AS AN EXTRA PERCENT REDUCTION OF LA TO TARGET CONCENTRATIONS 10% BELOW THE CRITERION.  THESE TMDLS ASSUMED THE EFFLUENTS DISCHARGE THE E. COLI DENSITY ALLOWED BY THE WLA OR 126/100 ML.  WWTF DISINFECTION SYSTEMS ARE OFTEN DESIGNED AND OPERATED TO ACHIEVE 100% REDUCTION IN THE INDICATOR BACTERIA OR 0/100ML.  THUS, THE ACTUAL NPDES PERMITTED POINT SOURCE CONTRIBUTION IS LIKELY LESS THAN EXPECTED BY THE TMDL.

THE ALLOWABLE POLLUTANT LOAD IS BASED UPON THE AVAILABLE STREAM FLOW VOLUME.  THAT IS, LOADING CAPACITIES ARE DEVELOPED FOR EACH FLOW BY MULTIPLYING THE WATER QUALITY STANDARD (WQS) BY THE SELECTED STREAM FLOW AND A CONVERSION FACTOR (C) WITH THE EQUATION BEING: 

LOADING CAPACITY = WQS * FLOW * C

DEFINING WATER BODY POLLUTANT LOADING CAPACITY IMPLIES A STEADY STATE.  THE DETERMINATION OF A LOADING CAPACITY FOR AMMONIA MUST CONSIDER THREE KEY VARIABLES: STREAM FLOW; PH; AND TEMPERATURE.  RATHER THAN RESTRICT THE LOADING CAPACITY TO A SINGLE FLOW, A DYNAMIC APPROACH IS USED.  THAT IS, LOADING CAPACITY ISESTABLISHED FOR THE ENTIRE HYDROGRAPH OF EACH SEASON WITH A LOAD DURATION CURVE.  

FOR E. COLI THE LC IS WQS*FLOW*C DURING THE RECREATIONAL SEASON.

THE NUMERIC TARGETS WILL RESULT IN THE ATTAINMENT OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS.

THIRTY DAY AVERAGE CONCENTRATIONS IN MG/L NOT TO EXCEED THE NUMERIC VALUE GIVEN BY

E. COLI WQS
SEGMENT LP2-20900 WAS INCLUDED ON CATEGORY 5 OF THE 2006 INTEGRATED REPORT AS HAVING AN IMPAIRED PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION BENEFICIAL USE WITH THE PARAMETER OF CONCERN BEING E. COLI BACTERIA.  THE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION BENEFICIAL USE APPLIES TO SURFACE WATERS WHICH ARE USED OR HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO BE USED FOR PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION, THAT INCLUDES ACTIVITIES WHERE THE BODY MAY COME INTO PROLONGED OR INTIMATE CONTACT WITH THE WATER SUCH THAT WATER MAY BE ACCIDENTALLY INGESTED OR SENSITIVE BODY ORGANS (E.G. EYES, EARS, NOSE) MAY BE EXPOSED.

THE WQS FOR E. COLI BACTERIA IS 126 CFM/100ML GEOMETRIC MEAN FIVE SAMPLES PER 30 DAY PERIOD DURING THE RECREATIONAL PERIOD (MAY 1 THROUGH SEPTEMBER 30).

THE TMDL TARGET IS BASED ON THE NUMERIC WATER QUALITY CRITERIA ASSOCIATED WITH THE CLASS B WARM WATER AQUATIC LIFE BENEFICIAL USE.

THE WATER QUALITY CRITERIA ESTABLISHED FOR THE CLASS B WARM WATER AQUATIC LIFE PROTECTION OF THE BENEFICIAL USED CAN BE FOUND IN THE TITLE 117, CHAPTER 4.  ASSESSMENT OF THE DATA AND THE TMDL ARE BASED ON THE CHRONIC CRITERION OF 12 UG/L.  THE LOAD ALLOCATION  (LC) ASSIGNED WILL BE BASED ON THE STREAM FLOW VOLUME AND IS DEFINED BY:

LC = FLOW X 12 UG/L X C

THIS TMDL WILL RESULT IN THE ATTAINMENT OF APPLICABLE WATER QUALITY STANDARD (WQS).THE POLLUTANT CAUSING THE IMPAIRMENT OF THE WQS AND DESIGNATED BENEFICIAL USE IS ATRAZINE.  DESIGNATED USES ASSIGNED TO THE ABOVE IDENTIFIED SEGMENTS INCLUDE:  PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION; AQUATIC LIFE WARMWATER CLASS B; AGRICULTURE SUPPLY CLASS A; AND AESTHETICS (NDEQ 2006B).  EXCESSIVE ATRAZINE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE IMPAIRING THE AQUATIC LIFE BENEFICIAL USE.  ASSESSMENT OF THE DATA AND THE TMDL ARE BASED ON THE CHRONIC CRITERION OF 12 UG/L.  BASED ON THE DATA ASSESSMENT PROCESS A SEASONAL CONCERN/IMPAIRMENT (MAY-JUNE) EXISTS FOR ATRAZINE.  BECAUSE THE IMPAIRMENT IS SEASONAL, THIS TMDL WILL FOCUS ON THAT PERIOD.THE TMDL TARGET IS BASED ON THE NUMERIC WATER QUALITY CRITERIA FOR ATRAZINE OF 12 UG/L.  
THE WLA AND NATURAL BACKGROUND IS SET AT ZERO (0).  THE LA IS BASED ON STREAM FLOW VOLUME.  THE 
ENTIRE LC IS THE LA, AN EXAMPLE AT THE 50% FLOW, THE LA WOULD BE 1.1 KG/DAY ATRAZINE.

MIDDLE CREEK WAS LISTED ON THE STATE OF NEBRASKAS 303(D) LIST FOR AN ATRAZINE IMPAIRMENT.  THE LOADING CAPACITY FOR MIDDLE CREEK HAS BEEN DIRECTLY LINKED TO THE CHRONIC WATER QUALITY STANDARD (WQS) FOR ATRAZINE, 12 MICROGRAMS PER LITER (UG/L).  USING A RANGE OF POTENTIAL FLOW DATA, MAXIMUM DAILY LOADS FOR MIDDLE CREEK ARE CALCULATED IN APPENDIX B OF THE TMDL TO MEET THE 12 UG/L WQS.  THESE RANGE FROM 0.03 KG/DAY TO 2.94 KG/DAY FOR FLOWS BETWEEN 1 CUBIC FEET PER SECOND (CFS) AND 100 CFS.  THE WQS ARE THE TARGET OR ENDPOINT OF THIS TMDL.  BASED ON THE ANALYTICAL DATA FOR MIDDLE CREEK, A 73% REDUCTION IS CALLED FOR IN THE TMDL.  IF THIS REDUCTION OCCURS, THE WATER BODY SHOULD MEET THE WQS.THE TMDL DESCRIBES ALL APPLICABLE WQS AND ALL BENEFICIAL USES (AQUATIC LIFE, AGRICULTURE WATER SUPPLY, AND AESTHETICS).  THE IMPAIRED USE IS THE AQUATIC LIFE USE.  THE TARGET IS A MAXIMUM CONCENTRATION OF 12 UG/L OF ATRAZINE, A STATE WQS, IN THE STREAM.LAND USE IN THE WATERSHED IS DESCRIBED AS MOSTLY AGRICULTURAL.  SINCE ATRAZINE IS ONE OF THE MOST COMMONLY USED PESTICIDES IN THE COUNTRY AND THE LAND USE IS DOMINATED BY AGRICULTURE, THE TMDL CONCLUDES THAT POINT SOURCES ARE NOT CONTRIBUTING ATRAZINE TO MIDDLE CREEK.  BECAUSE ATRAZINE DOES NOT OCCUR NATURALLY, NATURAL BACKGROUND IS SET AT ZERO AS WELL. IT SEEMS ALL SIGNIFICANT SOURCES HAVE BEEN CONSIDERED.

THE 2004 AND 2006 NE SWQ REPORT INCLUDED CARTER LAKE ON PART 5 SECTION 303(D)  FOR ALGAL TOXINS, TOTAL PHOSPHORUS, TOTAL NITROGEN, CHLOROPHYLL A, AND PH.  CARTER LAKE WAS INDLUDED ON THE IMPAIRED WATERS LIST DUE TO ALGAE AND TURBIDITY. NEBRASKA DOES NOT HAVE NUMERIC WATER QULAITY STANDARDS FOR LAKES THAT INCLUDE TOTAL PHOSPHORUS, TOTAL NITROGEN AND CHOLOPHYLL A.  HOWEVER, THE TMDL TARGET VALUES OFR TOTAL PHOSPHORUS (96UG/L) AND CHLOROPHYLL A (33UG/L) WILL MEET THE NE NARRATIVE STANDARDS.  THE PHOSPHORUS TARGET WAS DETERMINED USING THE CANFIELD-BACHMANN NATURAL LAKE MODEL AND THE EUTROMOD LOADING MODEL FUNCTION.  FOR TOTAL NITROGEN, THE TN:TP  RATIO INDICATES A PHOSPHORUS LIMITED SYSTEM. THE PHOSPHURUS TARGET WILL ACHEIVE A NARRATIVE TOTAL NITROGEN STANDARD.  ALGAL TOXINS PRODUCED BY BLUE GREEEN ALGAE HAVE BEEN SHOWN TO BE CORRELATED TO PHOSPHORUS, MEASURES OF TRANSPARENCY AND OVERALL CHLOROPHYLL OCNCENTRATIONS.  FOR PH, DURING PHOTOSYNTHESIS, THE PHYTOPLANKTON UPTAKE CARBON DIOXIDE AND GIVE OOF OXYGEN.  THE PH VALUE INCREASES WITH THE DECREASE IN AVAILABLE HYDROGEN CATIONS.  PEAKS IN PH SHOULD OCCUR INT HE AFTERNOON, WHEN THE GREATEST AMOUNT OF RADIANT ENERGY REACHES THE WATER.  DECREASING TOTAL PHOSPHORUS WILL REDUCE PHYTOPLANKTON AND DEVERASE THEIR EFFECT ON PH RESULTING INT HE LAKE MEETING THE PH STANDARD OF 6.5-9.0.  SEE THE TMDL FOR SPECIFIC LOADING INFORMATION.

The endpoint for the nutrient and dissolved oxygen TMDL is based on both narrative and numeric criteria and stakeholder water quality goals. As described below, phosphorus loading targets in comparison with current load estimates, allowed for the determination of an allowable load (i.e., desired endpoint), attain full support designation and the stakeholder water quality goals.

"Water Quality Standards Attainment:
The Designated Uses of Big Blue River Basin segments BB1-10000, BB1-20000, BB4-10000, BB4-20000, Mission Creek segment BB1-10100, Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10800, Turkey Creek segments BB2-10000, BB2-20000 and West Fork Big Blue River segments BB3-10000, BB3-20000 are:

Primary Contact Recreation,
Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A,  
Agriculture Water Supply Class A and
Aesthetics. 
 
The Designated Uses of Big Blue River segment BB4-40000, Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10900, Beaver Creek segment BB3-10300 and Lincoln Creek segment BB4-20800 are:

Warm Water Aquatic Life Class B,
Agriculture Water Supply Class A and
Aesthetics. 
 
Atrazine 
The Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A use of Big Blue River segments BB1-10000, BB1-20000, BB4-10000, Mission Creek segment BB1-10100, Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10800, Turkey Creek segments BB2-10000, BB2-20000 and West Fork Big Blue River segments BB3-10000, BB3-20000 is impaired as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The Warm Water Aquatic Life Class B use of Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10900, Beaver Creek segment BB3-10300, Lincoln Creek segment BB4-20800 and Big Blue River segment BB4-40000 is impaired as a result of the pollutant atrazine. The applicable numeric water quality criteria established for protection of the Warm Water Aquatic Life Class A use and Class B use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. The following criteria apply to all aquatic life use classes: 
 

""003.01C Toxic Substances. Surface waters shall be free from toxic substances, alone or in combination with other substances, in concentrations that result in acute or chronic toxicity to aquatic life, except as specified in Chapter 2. Toxic substances shall not be present in concentrations that result in objectionable tastes or significant bioaccumulation or biomagnification in aquatic organisms which renders them unsuitable or unsafe for consumption. (In implementing these criteria, the Department will follow procedures outlined in the State’s Continuing Planning Process which comply with the federal water quality standards, 40 C.F.R. § 131.11 (1987))."" 
 
Numerical criteria for the protection of aquatic life and their uses (e.g., fish consumption) shall not be exceeded. Acute criterion for atrazine is established at 330 micrograms per liter based on a one-hour average concentration; and the chronic criterion for atrazine is 12 micrograms per liter based on a four-day average concentration. Assessment of the data and TMDLs are based on the atrazine chronic criterion of 12 µg/L. 
 
Escherichia coli The Primary Contact Recreation use of Big Blue River segments BB1-10000, BB1-20000, BB4-10000, Mission Creek segment BB1-10100, Big Indian Creek segment BB1-10800, Turkey Creek segments BB2-10000, BB2-20000 and West Fork Big Blue River segments BB3-10000, BB3-20000, is impaired as a result of the pollutant E. coli. Water quality criteria established for the protection of the Primary Contact Recreation beneficial use can be found in Title 117, Chapter 4, Nebraska Surface Water Quality Standards, 2006. 
 

""002 Primary Contact Recreation. This use applies to surface waters which are used, or have a high potential to be used, for primary contact recreational activities. Primary contact recreation includes activities where the body may come into prolonged or intimate contact with the water, such that water may be accidentally ingested and sensitive body organs (e.g., eyes, ears, nose, etc.) may be exposed. Although the water may be accidentally ingested, it is not intended to be used as a potable water supply unless acceptable treatment is applied. These waters may be used for swimming, water skiing, canoeing and similar activities. These criteria apply during the recreational period of May 1 th"
